admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            for, the production and supply of potable water was
            increased, and, the institutional capacity of the Borrower
            was strengthened. The key lessons learned suggest that: 1)
            Project design should ensure long-term sustainability of
            investments, thus up-front institutional arrangements should
            be agreed early on, and, strong emphasis should be laid on a
            balanced investment - balance between production,
            distribution systems, and its operation/maintenance
            activities. This implies Bank financing should focus on
            complete works, rather than supply items, as proven by the
            successful installation, which was left to the Borrower,
            and, provision for complementary sewerage systems should be
            ensured for water projects. 2) Policy sector reforms
            require, broad-based and comprehensive emphasis on autonomy,
            and private sector participation, particularly for
            institutional, and financial successful performances. This
            allowed the Borrower to contribute significantly to project
            sustainability, and mobilize finances for needed future
            investments. 3) Implementation requires flexible responses
            to changing conditions, which may otherwise face delays,
            either in the provision of local currency funds, or cause
            serious implementation interruptions. Close cooperation with
            the Government and donors, will increase efficiency, as will
            a proactive Bank management, and restructuring practices.
